items.title: 12 Emotional Hours: A Spectator Reflects on One Full Day (Without Caffeine)
items.summary: Attending Charlie Kirk’s memorial involved lots of standing, worrying and waiting. But for one Colorado Springs woman, it was all worth it.

items.title: Trump Remembers Kirk as a Martyr While Attacking Political Opponents
items.summary: President Trump oscillated between honoring Charlie Kirk’s life and promoting his own political agenda in his remarks at the conservative activist’s memorial in Arizona.

items.title: Trump and Musk Are Seen Together at Kirk Memorial, Months After Falling-Out
items.summary: The meeting came just three months after Mr. Musk exited the government in a fit of rage, attacking the president on social media.

items.title: At Kirk Service, an Extraordinary Fusion of Government and Christianity
items.summary: The memorial reflected the degree to which conservative Christianity had melded with Republican politics in the Trump era.

items.title: The Conservative Figures That Attended the Charlie Kirk Memorial
items.summary: Led by President Trump, the list of guests included high-ranking members of his administration, conservative influencers and far-right media personalities.

items.title: ‘We Are All Charlie’: Thousands Stood in Line for Hours in Hopes of Paying Tribute
items.summary: Many endured stifling heat outside the stadium in Glendale, Ariz. Some who were turned away headed to a nearby arena, while others went home.

items.title: Trump news at a glance: president calls Charlie Kirk a ‘martyr’ at memorial
items.summary: <p>President says ‘I hate my opponents’; Kirk’s widow forgives shooter; Murdochs could be part of TikTok deal – key US politics stories from 21 September at a glance</p><p>Donald Trump gave a rambling, freewheeling address at the Charlie Kirk memorial in Alabama on Sunday, taking aim at Joe Biden and trailing a major announcement on autism as well as praising Kirk, who was shot dead on 10 September.</p><p>In front of a crowd of tens of thousands, Trump said Kirk was a “great American hero” and “martyr” for freedom. During the event he sat side-by-side with billionaire Elon Musk, a once trusted adviser with whom the US president had a spectacular public falling out.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/22/trump-administration-news-updates-latest">Continue reading...</a>
